station.name: CLASSICAL CROSSOVER
station.longDesc: Classical crossover - a musical style that represents a kind of synthesis, a harmonious combination of elements of classical music and pop, rock, electronic music. The name was officially established not so long ago, having entered the list of nominations for the Grammy Music Award, annually awarded by the US National Recording Academy.

station.name: RUSSIAN POP MUSIC
station.longDesc: Russian pop music is the collective name of popular music production of Russian and Russian-language pop music from the CIS countries, the Baltic States, and also abroad, in which songs are performed primarily in Russian, in the languages ​​of the CIS countries, and (less often) in other languages ​​of the world. Foreigners from far abroad, unfamiliar with Russia and the USSR, often do not distinguish between Soviet pop music, Russian pop music, Russian pop music, Russian-language pop music, although these concepts are not identical.

station.name: POP MUSIC 80's
station.longDesc: Pop music of the 80s is a separate layer of musical culture, which gave rise to almost all areas of the modern pop scene. Not by chance, as time passes, we often hear familiar melodies that sound fresh, albeit with some nostalgia. Disco, Eurodisco, Italodisk, here are the

on which pop music of that time was kept. Today, the number of styles and directions of pop music has noticeably increased, but despite all their diversity, each of them is influenced by precisely that epoch of the Disco era.

station.name: NU DISCO
station.longDesc: Nu-disco (eng. New disco disco) is a 21st century dance music genre associated with a renewed interest of listeners in disco music of the late 1970s and early 1980s, the italo disco of the mid 1980s and the synthesizer Eurodisco.

station.name: C-POP (CHINESE POP)
station.longDesc: Chinese pop music (C-Pop, Chinese Pop) - an abbreviation of the name of Chinese popular music, a freely defined music genre originating from mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, other countries where Chinese is used by a large population, such as Singapore and Malaysia. C-pop is sometimes used as an umbrella term, covering not only Chinese pop music, but also R & B, ballads, Chinese rock, Chinese hip-hop and Chinese ambient music, although Chinese rock became a separate genre in the early 1990s.

station.name: POP BALLADS
station.longDesc: Lyrical compositions of incredible beauty and harmony performed by famous artists.

station.name: POP MUSIC
station.longDesc: Pop music - the direction of modern music, a type of modern mass culture. The term 'pop music' has a double meaning. In a broad sense, this is any mass music (including rock, electronics, jazz, blues). In a narrow sense - a separate genre of popular music, directly pop music with certain characteristics.

station.name: ITALO DISCO
station.longDesc: Italo Disco is a music marketing term introduced in 1983 by Bernhard Mikulski, the founder of the record company ZYX Records. The term referred to Italian electronic dance music of the 1980s and to music from other parts of Europe and from North America, which imitated these sounds.

station.name: J-POP (JAPANESE POP)
station.longDesc: J-pop or jay-pop is a generic term for the classification of Japanese popular music, abbr. from English

. Sometimes the term is used for rock music in Japan, but for it basically another term J-rock is used. Because of this, many rock artists (not heavy directions) from Japan attribute some of their work to J-pop.

station.name: FRENCH CHANSON
station.longDesc: Chanson (fr. Chanson - song) is a genre of vocal music. French chandeliers used a genre of chanson in the late 19th century - first half of the 20th century. The most famous of them are Aristide Bruan, Mistingett. From the cabaret, this modification of chanson moved to the French pop music of the XX century.

station.name: FRENCH POP
station.longDesc: French pop music - pop music played in French. Usually by musicians from France, Canada, Belgium, Switzerland or any other French speaking region of the world. The target audience is the French-language music market (primarily France), which is much smaller and largely independent of the mainstream market of English-speaking musicians.

station.name: K-POP (KOREAN POP)
station.longDesc: K-pop (an abbreviation of English Korean pop) is a musical genre that originated in South Korea and incorporates elements of Western electropop, hip-hop, dance music and modern rhythm and blues. Appearing initially as a musical genre, K-pop has become a large-scale musical subculture with millions of fans among young people all over the world.

station.name: EURODANCE
station.longDesc: Eurodance (from Eurodance - European and dance - dance) is a collective term for the direction of European electronic dance music, which appeared in the late 1980s at the confluence of techno, house and elements of European disco and had a popularity peak in the early to mid-90 -h. Nowadays, the popularity of this trend (rather than style as such) has declined significantly.

station.name: EURO DISCO
station.longDesc: Eurodisco (euro disco) is a term that unites the genres of electronic dance music that originated in Europe in the 1980s - electropop and disco along with new derivatives from them, such as Hi-NRG, Italo Disco, House, Europop and others. A typical Eurodisc song is based on the use of a synthesizer, drum machine, bright bass and is usually sung on high tones. In the 1980s, the term was rarely used in Europe, where such music was and was simply considered pop or disco music.

station.name: DISCO
station.longDesc: Disco (English Disco, lit. 'disco') - one of the main genres of dance music of the XX century, which arose in the early 1970s. Disco almost simultaneously developed in the USA and Europe. The development of the genre was mainly influenced by such styles of music as funk, Latin American music and soul music.

station.name: EUROBEAT/HI-NRG
station.longDesc: Eurobeat (English Eurobeat) - the genre of electronic music, which appeared in the late 1980s, a form of early British dance pop, is a combination of two genres, Italo Disco and Hi-NRG. Genre is characterized by hard synth sound. Early compositions (until the mid-90s) differed by an average tempo (125 - 150 BPM), the later ones had a faster tempo (140 - 190 BPM) and were often accompanied by hard electric guitars.

station.name: SCHLAGER
station.longDesc: Schlager (German: Schlager- literally: action (from German. Schlag- strike); best-selling product, the highlight of the season, synonymous with a song-hit) - popular for a period of time, a fashionable song with a catchy tune (usually pop) single or in general any work of various genres that are particularly popular.

station.name: RUSSIAN POP MUSIC 80's
station.longDesc: In the early 1980s, Russian-language music from the Soviet period was on the rise. During this period Raymond Pauls, a talented Latvian composer, creates. Many musical compositions, such as The Million Scarlet Roses, created during this period will then become almost classical examples.

station.name: ARABIC POP MUSIC
station.longDesc: Arabic pop music is pop music performed in Arabic and popular mainly in the Arab world. Most of this music was produced in the Egyptian capital Cairo, before the civil war in Lebanon, Beirut was also a major production center. The development of Arab popular music is associated with the Arab film industry, the center of which is also Cairo. Stylistically, the genre is based on pop-rhythms traditional for the Western world with elements of regional varieties of Arab traditional music.

station.name: LATIN POP
station.longDesc: Latin American pop music (English Latin Pop, Spanish Pop Latino) is the main subgenre of Latin American music. It is mainly performed in Spanish and Portuguese, less often in Spanglish (a mixture of English and Spanish), in some cases in English. The main instruments for performing Latin American music are the Spanish guitar, accordion, saxophone, African drums.

station.name: DANCE POP
station.longDesc: Dance-pop is an electronic dance music style and a sub-genre of pop music that evolved from the post-disco era around 1981, and combined dance rhythms with pop, house and / or song structure with modern rhythm n-blues. Appearing in the mid-80s, this style was a reflection of the composers' attempts to express the potential of pop music with the help of new electronic instruments.

station.name: ITALO POP
station.longDesc: Italy's music is multifaceted, like the country itself. It’s hard to imagine a person who has never heard the names of such masters of classical music as Giuseppe Verdi and Joacino Rossini, Nicolo Paganini and Antonio Vivaldi.
